1816.description:
- Children with moderate to severe malnutrition, significant hemoptysis, significant loss of weight, cough or fever >=2 weeks, known close TB contact in past 12 months with respiratory complaints, should be evaluated for TB infection
-	Refer for TB assessment or if TB assessment performed at this health facility, follow in-house protocol. 
-	If patient is stable, do not give antibiotics until specimen collection is completed

- Children with moderate to severe malnutrition, significant hemoptysis, significant loss of weight, cough or fever >=2 weeks, known close TB contact in past 12 months with respiratory complaints, should be evaluated for TB infection
-	Refer for TB assessment or if TB assessment performed at this health facility, follow in-house protocol. 
-	If patient is stable, do not give antibiotics until specimen collection is completed

1862.description:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants.
- Also give thick porridge or well mashed foods, including animal source foods and vitamin A-rich fruits and vegetables.
- Start by giving 2 to 3 tablespoons of food. Gradually increase to 1/2 cups (1 cup = 250 ml). Give 2 to 3 meals each day.
- Offer 1 or 2 snacks each day between meals when the child seems hungry.

1863.description:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants.
- Also give a variety of mashed or finely chopped family food, including animal source foods and vitamin A-rich fruits and vegetables.
-Give 1/2 cup at each meal(1 cup = 250 ml).
- Give 3 to 4 meals each day.
- Offer 1 or 2 snacks between meals. The child will eat if hungry.
- For snacks, give small chewable items that the child can hold. Let your child try to eat the snack, but provide help if needed.

1864.description:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants.
- Also give a variety of mashed or finely chopped family food, including animal source foods and vitamin A-rich fruits and vegetables.
-Give 3/4 cup at each meal (1 cup = 250 ml).
- Give 3 to 4 meals each day.
- Offer 1 or 2 snacks between meals.
- Continue to feed your child slowly, patiently. Encourage - but do not force - your child to eat.
- For snacks, give small chewable items that the child can hold. Let your child try to eat the snack, but provide help if needed.

1865.description:
- Give a variety of family foods to your child, including animal source foods and vitamin rich fruits and vegetables.
- Give at least 1 full cup (250 ml) at each meal.
- Give 3 to 4 meals each day.
- Offer 1 or 2 snacks between meals.
- If your child refuses a new food, offer "tastes" several times. Show that you like the food.
Be patient.
- Talk with your child during a meal, and keep eye contact.

1808.description: Refer urgently with caretaker for inpatient management at a health centre or hospital with sufficient capacity to manage the illness of the patient. If referral is not possible, manage the child as described in the national guidelines or WHO Pocket Book for hospital care for children.

1769.description:
"No referral is needed.

Advise the caretaker to bring back the child if the child presents: 
- At any time: Respiratory distress, worsening of difficulty in breathing, is not able to drink or breastfeed, convulsions, new fever, new episode of blood in stool, if the child becomes unconscious, lethargic, or becomes sicker
- After 3 days: Persisting fever
- After 7 days: No improvement of symptoms (some symptoms such as oral aphtous ulcers, oral candidiasis, some skin lesions/rashes may take more than 7 days to improve)

*Consider scheduled follow-up or referral if the child is malnourished, has uncontrolled HIV, or other severe comorbidities.

(adapted from IMCI 2014, based on studies from Kallander et al. PLoS Med, 2018; and Mullany et al. PLoS Med, 2018)

1812.description:
"The child may be eating much less, or eating different foods during illness. Children often lose their appetite during illness. However, they should still be encouraged to eat the types of food recommended for their age, as often as recommended, even if they do not eat much. They should be offered their favourite nutritious foods, if possible, to encourage eating. Offer small feedings frequently. After illness, good feeding helps make up for any weight loss and prevent malnutrition.

During illness an infant or young child loses fluid due to fever, fast breathing, or diarrhoea. The child will feel better and stay stronger if he or she drinks extra fluid to prevent dehydration. Frequent breastfeeding will give the infant nourishment and help prevent dehydration. (IMCI Handbook)"

1815.description:
-           Soothe the throat and relieve the cough with a safe remedy, such as tea with lemon, lime, or honey.
-       Drink fluids: Fluids keep the throat moist and prevent dehydration.
-       Clear secretions from child using a cloth soaked in water that has been twisted to form a pointed wick
(Adapted from IMCI 2014, and Mayo Clinic 2020)

1769.description:
"No referral is needed.

Advise the caretaker to bring back the child if the child presents: 
- At any time: Respiratory distress, worsening of difficulty in breathing, is not able to drink or breastfeed, convulsions, new fever, new episode of blood in stool, if the child becomes unconscious, lethargic, or becomes sicker
- After 3 days: Persisting fever
- After 7 days: No improvement of symptoms (some symptoms such as oral aphtous ulcers, oral candidiasis, some skin lesions/rashes may take more than 7 days to improve)

*Consider scheduled follow-up or referral if the child is malnourished, has uncontrolled HIV, or other severe comorbidities.

(adapted from IMCI 2014, based on studies from Kallander et al. PLoS Med, 2018; and Mullany et al. PLoS Med, 2018)

1818.description:
-	Cold compresses: fill a bowl with cold water or with ice and water, submerge a clean towel or washcloth into the bowl and then wring it out. Apply it on the eye for 10-20 min, repeat after 2h
-	Advice about high contagiosity, importance of hand hygiene for patient and family members

1769.description:
"No referral is needed.

Advise the caretaker to bring back the child if the child presents: 
- At any time: Respiratory distress, worsening of difficulty in breathing, is not able to drink or breastfeed, convulsions, new fever, new episode of blood in stool, if the child becomes unconscious, lethargic, or becomes sicker
- After 3 days: Persisting fever
- After 7 days: No improvement of symptoms (some symptoms such as oral aphtous ulcers, oral candidiasis, some skin lesions/rashes may take more than 7 days to improve)

*Consider scheduled follow-up or referral if the child is malnourished, has uncontrolled HIV, or other severe comorbidities.

(adapted from IMCI 2014, based on studies from Kallander et al. PLoS Med, 2018; and Mullany et al. PLoS Med, 2018)

"No referral is needed.

Advise the caretaker to bring back the child if the child presents: 
- At any time: Respiratory distress, worsening of difficulty in breathing, is not able to drink or breastfeed, convulsions, new fever, new episode of blood in stool, if the child becomes unconscious, lethargic, or becomes sicker
- After 3 days: Persisting fever
- After 7 days: No improvement of symptoms (some symptoms such as oral aphtous ulcers, oral candidiasis, some skin lesions/rashes may take more than 7 days to improve)

*Consider scheduled follow-up or referral if the child is malnourished, has uncontrolled HIV, or other severe comorbidities.

(adapted from IMCI 2014, based on studies from Kallander et al. PLoS Med, 2018; and Mullany et al. PLoS Med, 2018)

1843.description:
-	Provide health education on safe sex
-	Discuss importance of using condoms to prevent acquisition of STIs, HIV, and unwanted pregnancies. 
-	Provide condoms if available

1769.description:
"No referral is needed.

Advise the caretaker to bring back the child if the child presents: 
- At any time: Respiratory distress, worsening of difficulty in breathing, is not able to drink or breastfeed, convulsions, new fever, new episode of blood in stool, if the child becomes unconscious, lethargic, or becomes sicker
- After 3 days: Persisting fever
- After 7 days: No improvement of symptoms (some symptoms such as oral aphtous ulcers, oral candidiasis, some skin lesions/rashes may take more than 7 days to improve)

*Consider scheduled follow-up or referral if the child is malnourished, has uncontrolled HIV, or other severe comorbidities.

(adapted from IMCI 2014, based on studies from Kallander et al. PLoS Med, 2018; and Mullany et al. PLoS Med, 2018)

1843.description:
-	Provide health education on safe sex
-	Discuss importance of using condoms to prevent acquisition of STIs, HIV, and unwanted pregnancies. 
-	Provide condoms if available

1816.description:
- Children with moderate to severe malnutrition, significant hemoptysis, significant loss of weight, cough or fever >=2 weeks, known close TB contact in past 12 months with respiratory complaints, should be evaluated for TB infection
-	Refer for TB assessment or if TB assessment performed at this health facility, follow in-house protocol. 
-	If patient is stable, do not give antibiotics until specimen collection is completed

2023.description:
-	Tell the mother to give extra fluid 
-	Breastfeed frequently and for longer at each feed
-	If the child is exclusively breastfed, give ORS or clean water in addition to breast milk 
-	If the child is not exclusively breastfed, give one or more of the following: ORS Solution, food-based fluids (such as soup, rice water, yoghurt drinks) or clean water
-	when the child cannot return to a clinic if the diarrhea gets worse, it is especially important to give ORS at home 
-	Give the mother at least 2 packets of ORS to use at home
-	Give additional fluid
-	2m-2y: 50-100ml after each loose stool
-	> 2y: 100-200ml after each loose stool
-	Give frequent small sips from a cup (or a spoon)
-	If the child vomits, wait 10 min. Then continue, but more slowly
-	Continue giving extra fluid until diarrhea stops 
-	Continue feeding (exclusive breastfeeding if age less than 6 months)
REF IMCI 2014

1769.description:
"No referral is needed.

Advise the caretaker to bring back the child if the child presents: 
- At any time: Respiratory distress, worsening of difficulty in breathing, is not able to drink or breastfeed, convulsions, new fever, new episode of blood in stool, if the child becomes unconscious, lethargic, or becomes sicker
- After 3 days: Persisting fever
- After 7 days: No improvement of symptoms (some symptoms such as oral aphtous ulcers, oral candidiasis, some skin lesions/rashes may take more than 7 days to improve)

*Consider scheduled follow-up or referral if the child is malnourished, has uncontrolled HIV, or other severe comorbidities.

(adapted from IMCI 2014, based on studies from Kallander et al. PLoS Med, 2018; and Mullany et al. PLoS Med, 2018)

1808.description: Refer urgently with caretaker for inpatient management at a health centre or hospital with sufficient capacity to manage the illness of the patient. If referral is not possible, manage the child as described in the national guidelines or WHO Pocket Book for hospital care for children.

2171.label: YICC Generalized symptom: possible serious systemic infection (pSBI); respiratory problem

2151.label: YI - IMCI clinical severe infection /severe disease

420.label: Fever without obvious source
420.description:
Only select this if the patient has fever and none of the following:

- NO Cough or difficult breathing
- NO Sore throat, runny nose, or ear infection
- NO Abscess, skin infection, chicken pox, measles rash, or other rash explaining the fever
- NO Diarrhea, vomiting, or severe abdominal pain
- NO Urinary symptoms
- NO Limp, single joint pain, joint swelling, pain or refusal to move extremity

437.label: Prevention and screening
437.description: HIV screening, vaccination status, deworming, vitamin A supplementation

461.label: General
461.description:
This is a mandatory branch to be assessed in all children.

Diagnoses that are developed within this complaint category include:
Malnutrition, anemia, malaria, TB screening, CNS danger signs, prolonged fever, simple convulsion, Suspicion of meningitis

299.label: Trauma, joint/limb pain, burns, wounds, poisoning
299.description:
Symptoms/signs: joint swelling/pain, limp, extremity pain, wound, burn, head trauma, car accident, smoke exposure, accidental ingestion of potentially harmful entity

Diagnoses: Osteomyelitis, septic arthritis, limp or joint pain, wound, fracture, dislocation, contusion, burn, head injury, car accident, inhalation injury, poisoning

264.label: Neurological manifestations (Headache,  stiff neck, neck pain)
264.description:
Symptoms: Headache, stiff neck, neck pain

Diagnoses: Suspicion of meningitis, non severe headache

12.label: Ear/Nose/Mouth/Throat complaint (including ear pain/discharge and sore throat)
12.description:
Symptoms: tooth pain, ear discharge, ear pain, mouth pain, mouth lesions, sore throat, neck mass, runny nose, cheek swelling

Diagnoses: Dental abscesses, tooth pain, ear infections, mastoiditis, foreign body in ear, oral ulcers, oral candidiasis, pharyngitis, lymphadenitis, lymphadenopathy, rhinitis, mumps

13.label: Respiratory Complaint (Cough or Difficult Breathing)
13.description:
Symptoms including: Cough, difficult breathing, stridor, barking cough, spitting blood (hemoptysis)

Diagnoses include: Respiratory distress, Cough or cold, croup, pneumonia, hemoptysis, reactive airway disease, suspicion of foreign object in airways, Suspicion of TB

10.label: Skin and hair complaint (Rashes, skin lesions, lice, measles, etc.)
10.description:
Includes: 
Abscess, cellulitis, impetigo, chicken pox, herpes, fungal skin infections, scabies, urticaria/anaphylaxis, eczema, measles, molluscum contagiosum, non-specific viral rash, head lice, diaper rash, scarlett fever, folliculitis, heat rash

11.label: Eye complaint (red eye, itching, pain, etc)
11.description:
Symptoms/signs: red eye, swelling, eye trauma, eye pain, eye itching, eye discharge
Diagnoses: Conjunctivitis, preseptal/orbital cellulitis, corneal abrasion, severe eye disease

213.label: Urine, genital and anal symptoms (including STIs, urinary tract infection)
213.description:
Symptoms/signs: inguinal/scrotal pain or swelling, pain or difficulty on passing urine, anal itching, Suspicion of pregnancy, very painful menstruation, penil or vaginal discharge, genital lesions, genital irritation or local pain

Diagnoses: Balanitis, Vulvovaginitis, Presumed gonorrhea/chlamydia/trichomoniasis/bacterial vaginosis, Vaginal Candidiasis, Pelvic Inflammatory Disease, Presumed Primary Syphilis, Genital herpes, Lower and upper urinary tract infection, Dysmenorrhea, pregnancy, oxyuriasis, Presumed testicular torsion, Inguinal hernia

275.label: Gastrointestinal symptoms (diarrhea, vomiting, trouble eating)
275.description:
Symptoms/signs: diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain, blood in stool, trouble eating, anal itching

Diagnoses: Dehydration, diarrhea, dysentery, constipation, loss of appetite, oxyuriasis, Severe abdominal condition

2179.label: Phone +255(0)
2179.description: Please add the 9 digits of the caregiver's phone number (without the initial 0) for the follow-up call. Just the digits (no space, dash, comma, period)
2179.min_message_error: Please enter a valid 9-digit Tanzanian phone number (without the +255 or the initial 0). Just the digits, no other character.
2179.max_message_error: Please enter a valid 9-digit Tanzanian phone number (without the +255 or the initial 0). Just the digits, no other character.

2180.label: Other phone +255(0)
2180.description: Please add the 9 digits of the caregiver's phone number (without the initial 0) for the follow-up call. Just the digits (no space, dash, comma, period)
2180.min_message_error: Please enter a valid 9-digit Tanzanian phone number (without the +255 or the initial 0). Just the digits, no other character.
2180.max_message_error: Please enter a valid 9-digit Tanzanian phone number (without the +255 or the initial 0). Just the digits, no other character.

2095.label: Sick young infant aged up to 2 months

33.label: Blood oxygen saturation (%)
33.description: Must be measured when infant or child is calm

5.label: Respiratory rate (breaths/min)
5.description: Must be when young infant or child is calm
5.max_message_warning: Repeat the count if it is 60 or more breaths per minute in a young infant aged up to months. THe young infant must be calm.

4.label: Heart rate (beats per minute)
4.description:
Record the patient's heart rate from previous pulse oximetry measurement.

The pulse oximeter shows a plethysmographic waveform (Pleth), ensure that the waveform  is uniform. 
Remember to measure the heart rate in a calm child, if the child is uncooperative, try to distract the child by talking or singing.

Note: Artifactual reasons for poor waveform may include: probe improperly applied, slippage of the probe, the probe has come off of the patient, excessive movement of the patient, and poor cable connections.
 Note: It is normal for there to be a smaller wave after the larger wave, as long as the pattern is regular

(REF: Adapted from Sepsis CoLab 2020)
4.max_message_warning:
The value you have entered is very high.
The optimal maximal accuracy limit for the lifebox pulse oxymeter for heart rate is 240 bpm. 
This is +60bpm above the 99 percentile in a child 0-3 months, and +130 bpm above the 99 percentile in a 15 years old child.  Please measure again, and make sure to put in the correct value.
4.min_message_error:
The value you have entered is bellow 20 beats per minute.
This is -27 to -90 bpm compared to healthy children at the 1st percentile of heart beats.
Please measure it again.
4.max_message_error: The value you have entered is over 340, this is most likely an error, please measure the value again.

40.label: Difficulty breathing
40.description: Difficult breathing is any unusual pattern of breathing. Mothers describe this in different ways, They may say that their childs breathing is "fast", "noisy" or "interrupted".  (IMCI 2014)

34.label: Grunting
34.description:
"Does the child have a grunt (Short noise at each expiration) on expiration ? 
Grunting is characterized as repetitive eh sounds, usually short in duration, during early expiration against a partially closed glottis. Represents the childs attempt to generate additional positive end expiratory pressure and maintain lung volume. (REF: Adapted from Pediatric Sepsis CoLab 2020 and McCollum, et al. CID, 2017)"

18.label: Chest indrawing
18.description:
Does the child have chest indrawing on inspiration? 
the abnormal inward movement of subcostal tissue (ie, the tissue inferior to the costal cartilage of the lower anterior chest wall) during inspiration 
(REF: adpated from Pediatric Sepsis CoLab 2020 and IMCI, 2014)

62.label: Severe difficult breathing needing referral
62.description:
This is a subjective assessment, if you feel that the patient has such severe difficult breathing that they most likely need to be referred or admitted for supportive care, select this as yes.
Signs of severe difficult breathing needing referral often present with labored and rapid breathing resulting in muscle fatigue, confusion and general weakness. Often associated with severe chest indrawing, nasal flaring and grunting.

Note, chest indrawing alone is not a sufficient criteria to refer or admit a child.

(World Health Organization. Pocket book of hospital care for children: guidelines for the management of common childhood illnesses. 2013)
-

82.label: Improvement after one hour after treatment

63.label: Stridor
63.description: Does the child have a stridor? When the child breathes in, it make a squeaky, high pitched noise from the upper airways (adapted from Pediatric Sepsis CoLab 2020)

19.label: Stridor in calm child
19.description:
"When the child is calm and breathes in, it makes a squeaky, high-pitched noise.
If a child is excited, or moving around stridor is more present, it is important to see if it is also present when the child is calm. This means it is more severe."

37.label: Possibility of foreign object in airway ? (Choking episode?)
37.description:
Select this if you or the caretaker suspects that the stridor or difficulty in breathing is due to a foreign object stuck in the airways. 
If yes, this is an emergency

64.label: Barking cough
64.description: Cough that sounds like a seal or a dog. Often, the child's voice is also hoarse.

122.label: CRP
122.description:
CRP TEST INSTRUCTIONS (see specific SOP)
-        Take 10micoL blood from finger prick and dopt it into the Specimen Dilution Buffer tube
-        Mix the sample into the buffer by inverting the tube upside down 10-15 times until you see no visible whole blood in the capillary.
-        Place the dipstick yellow dip area (the lower end of the dipstick) into the diluted sample and hold it there until you see the liquid front enter the result area. Remove the dipstick from the solution and place it in a horizontal position.

INTERPRETATION:
-        Read results within 5 minutes. Do not pay attention to any lines appearing later than 5 minutes. 
-        The red (control) line confirms the correct performance of the test.
-        If, in addition to the red control line there are
o        no blue lines, the serum CRP concentration of the sample is <10 mg/l
o        one blue line, the serum CRP concentration is 10-40 mg/l
o        two blue lines, the serum CRP concentration is 40-80 mg/l
o        three blue lines, the serum CRP concentration is >80 mg/l
-        If the red (control) line does not appear, the test is invalid and the test must be performed again.
-        Document the results of the test as per usual health facility procedures with the result CRP <10mg/l, CRP 10-40mg/l, or CRP >80mg/l

1666.label: >= 2 months < 6 months; >=6 months < 5 years; >= 5 years < 12 years; >= 12 years < 15 years

1687.label: Significant hemoptysis (>1 episode)
1687.description:
Hemoptysis = coughing blood more than once. 
Not to be confused with coughing blood after nose bleed, lesion in mouth, or vomiting blood, these are different, if this is the case, select no.

25.label: History of fever
25.description:
Ask: ""Has the child had a fever within the last 48 hours?""
Meaning there was temperature measured at >=38C, or if not measured, the child was abnormally hot upon touching the uncovered child over the past 48 hours. (REF Adapted from Sepsis CoLab, IMCI 2014)"

93.label: Malaria rapid diagnostic test
93.description:
**Follow normal health facility procedures**

Bellow are suggested guidance in the case that normal health facility procedures are not clear:

TEST PROCEDURES FOR:  "CareStart Malaria Pf (HRP2) Ag rapid test":
        Apply 5l of whole blood sample to the sample well S of CareStart Malaria Pf (HRP2) Ag rapid
test and add 60l assay buffer solution (2-3 drops) into the A well. 
        Interpret the results within 20 minutes.

INTERPRETATION OF RESULTS:

POSITIVE (two bars): 
Red bars appear in both the control window (labeled C) and the patient window (labeled T) of the strip. The test result is positive even if the patient bar
appears lighter or darker than the control bar.

NEGATIVE (one bar): 
One red bar appears in the control window of the strip (labelled "C") and no red bar appears in the patient window of the strip (labelled "T").

INVALID (no bar): If there is no red bar in the control window of the strip, and even if a red bar appears in the patient window of the strip, the result is invalid and should be repeated.  If it is still invalid dont use the whole box of test kits from which the kit used was taken off.

91.label: Microscopy for malarial parasites
91.description:
**Follow normal health facility procedures**

Bellow are suggested guidance in the case that normal health facility procedures are not clear:

Test procedure:
        Whole blood sample from the fingertip (or heel of an infant) or peripheral blood from venipucture can be used. 
        Prepare the blood smear (thick and/or thin smears) for staining using 10% Giemsa staining solution as per SOP.
        Read the blood smears using 100x objectives under an oil immersion.
     o        Thick blood smear for detecting the presence of parasites
     o        Thin blood smear for malaria species identification

89.label: Number of convulsions in present illness

88.label: Convulsions in present illness
88.description:
HAS THE CHILD HAD CONVULSIONS?
During a convulsion, the childs arms and legs stiffen because the muscles are contracting. The child may lose consciousness or not be able to respond to spoken directions. 

Ask the mother if the child has had convulsions during this current illness. Use words the mother understands. For example, the mother may know convulsions as fits or spasms.

REF: WHO, IMCI 2005

124.label: IMCI fast breathing
124.description: IMCI/IMAI fast breathing threshold in breaths/minutes

110.label: Hemoglobin (g/L)
110.description:
**Follow normal health facility procedures**

Bellow are suggested guidance in the case that normal health facility procedures are not clear:

Test procedure:
        Puncture the middle or ring finger using a lancet and fill the
microcuvette in one continuous process. Do NOT refill and avoid bubbles
        Place the filled microcuvette in the cuvette holder and slide the holder
to the measuring position. 
        After 15-60 seconds read the haemoglobin value displayed.

** The Hemocue Hb 201+ system should be verified routinely using
commercially available haematology controls
110.min_message_warning: This hemoglobin is very low, which means the patient has severe anemia and needs to be referred for inpatient management. Please double check the result to be sure this is the correct value.
110.max_message_warning: This value is higher than normal values, please double check that the value you have inserted is correct.
110.min_message_error: The value inputted is <10g/L which is incompatible with life. Please double check the value or perform the test again.
110.max_message_error: The value inputted is above 256g/L which is above the hemocue threshold, please double check the result.

108.label: Some conjunctival pallor
108.description: Conjunctivae with neither clearly red nor clearly pale anterior rims or those in which one conjunctiva is pale and the other is normal (REF Aggarwal et al. Anemia 2014)

109.label: Some palmar pallor
109.description: LOOK at the skin of the childs palm. Hold the childs palm open by grasping it gently from the side. Do not stretch the fingers backwards.  This may cause pallor by blocking the blood supply. If it looks pale compared to the caretaker, then palmar pallor is present. (adapted from IMCI 2014)

49.label: Suspected reactive airway disease: Attempt trial of bronchodilator
49.description:
Give Inhaled Salbutamol (use spacer especially in children under 5 years). After proper use, assess if there is a subjective improvement (child describes an improvement of breathing) or objective improvement (respiratory rate reduces, or chest indrawing stops)

USE OF A SPACER*
A spacer is a way of delivering the bronchodilator drugs effectively into the lungs. No child under 5 years
should be given an inhaler without a spacer. A spacer works as well as a nebuliser if correctly used.
 
Spacers can be made in the following way:
Use a 500ml drink bottle or similar.
Cut a hole in the bottle base in the same shape as the mouthpiece of the inhaler.
This can be done using a sharp knife.
Cut the bottle between the upper quarter and the lower 3/4 and disregard the upper quarter of the bottle.
Cut a small V in the border of the large open part of the bottle to fit to the child's nose and be used as a mask.
Flame the edge of the cut bottle with a candle or a lighter to soften it.
In a small baby, a mask can be made by making a similar hole in a plastic (not polystyrene) cup.
Alternatively commercial spacers can be used if available.
To use an inhaler with a spacer:
Remove the inhaler cap. Shake the inhaler well.
Insert mouthpiece of the inhaler through the hole in the bottle or plastic cup.
The child should put the opening of the bottle into his mouth and breath in and out through the mouth.
A carer then presses down the inhaler and sprays into the bottle while the child continues to breath normally.
Wait for three to four breaths and repeat.

For younger children place the cup over the child's mouth and use as a spacer in the same way.
* If a spacer is being used for the first time, it should be primed by 4-5 extra puffs from the inhaler.

125.label: age < 2 months/ 2 to 12 months / 12 months to 5 years / 5 to 14 years / >=14 years

41.label: Wheezing
41.description: Wheezing is a high-pitched, whistling sound a child makes when breathing, especially when exhaling. It happens when the airways are tightened, or inflamed, often in the case of reactive airway disease (asthma).

222.label: Abnormal vaginal discharge
222.description:
Vaginal discharge is fluid that comes from the vagina. Normal discharge helps to keep the vagina clean and moist to prevent infections. Normal vaginal discharge is clear, white or off-white in color. 

Abnormal discharge is a change in colour, odor, or quantity. Abnormal colour include greenish color, or anything looking like pus, or foaming or cottage-cheese-like discharge.

221.label: Pain or difficulty urinating
221.description: painful urinary voiding (alguria) or burning/stinging sensation during difficult urination (dysuria)

268.label: Age < 12 months; >= 12 to 35 months; >= 3 years to 14 years

224.label: Urinary analysis
224.description:
COLLECTION INSTRUCTION: 
	The patient should be instructed to collect fresh middle streaming urine and fill at least half of the collection container.

INTERPRETATION:
Pathologic test (Positive) = 
>=10 leukocytes/mm3 in un-centrifuged sample
OR
>= 5 leukocytes/mm3 high-power field in centrifuged sample
OR
Positive leukocyte esterase and nitrite

Normal test: 
<10 leukocytes/mm3 in un-centrifuged sample
OR
< 5 leukocytes/mm3 high-power field in centrifuged sample
OR
Negative leukocyte esterase and nitrite

129.label: Measles rash and associated signs
129.description:
In measles, a red rash begins 2 to 4 days after the start of a fever, starting behind the ears and on the neck. It spreads to the face. During the next day, the rash spreads to the rest of the body, arms and legs. After 4 to 5days, the rash starts to fade and the skin may peel. Some children with severe infection may have more rash spread over more of the body. The rash becomes more discolored(dark brown or blackish), and there is more peeling of the skin.
A measles rash does not have vesicles (blisters) or pustules. The rash does not itch. Do not confuse measles with other common childhood rashes such as chicken pox, scabiesor heat rash. 
The rash is often associated with red eyes, runny nose or cough.
REF WHO IMCI Hanbook 2005

30.label: Pus is draining from the eye
30.description: Pus (white-yellow discharge) draining  from  the  eye  is  a  sign  of  conjunctivitis.  Conjunctivitis is an infection of the conjunctiva, the inside surface of the eyelid and the white part of the eye. If you do not see pus draining from the eye, look for pus on the conjunctiva or on the eyelids. Often the pus forms a crust when the child is sleeping and seals the eye shut. You can gently open the eye, making sure that your hands are clean. Wash your hands after examining the eye of any child with pus draining from the eye.

68.label: Sticky eye
68.description: Gluing of the eye, especially on waking

160.label: >= 2 months to 6months / >= 6 months to 59 months / 5 years to 14 years

67.label: Redness and swelling around eye
67.description: Eyelids are red, warm, tender and edematous

2251.label: Is oral Amoxicillin / clavulanic acid available ?

32.label: History of injury of eye region

140.label: Clouding of the cornea
140.description:
The cornea is usually clear. When clouding of the cornea is present, the cornea may appear clouded or hazy. The cornea may look the way a glass of water looks when you add a small amount of milk. The clouding may occur in one or both eyes. 
Corneal clouding is a dangerous condition. It may be the result of vitamin A deficiency that has been made worse by measles. If the corneal clouding is not treated, the cornea can ulcerate and cause blindness. 
A child with clouding of the cornea needs urgent treatment with vitamin A. A  child  with  corneal  clouding  may  keep  his  or  her  eyes  tightly  shut  when  exposed  to  light.  The  light  may  cause  irritation and pain to the childs eyes. To check the childs eye, wait for the child to open his or her eye. Or gently pull down the lower eyelid to look for clouding.
If there is clouding of the cornea, ask the caregiver how long the clouding has been present. If the caregiver is certain that clouding has been there for some time, ask if the clouding has already been assessed and treated at the hospital. If it has, you do not need to refer this child again for corneal clouding.

250.label: Very painful menstruation
250.description: Cramps or throbbing pain in the lower abdomen/lower back during menstruation, sometimes accompanied by nausea, vomiting or fatigue.

164.label: Dental abscess
164.description: A dental abscess is a collection of pus in the teeth, or gums.

1691.label: Suspicion of foreign object in ear
1691.description: Suspicion of foreign object in ear, usually accompanied with a lot of ear discharge.

1689.label: Hearing loss
1689.description: Reduced hearing from the affected ear

220.label: History of sexual contact?
220.description: Sexual contact is defined as any sexual activity, including vaginal intercourse, anal sex, or oral sex

2018.label: Suspicion of pregnancy?
2018.description:
Missed period and recent unprotected vaginal sex.
Note: women can have light irregular bleeding during pregnancy, but much less than their normal period.

1833.label: Removal of object
1833.description: Use clean water to irrigate ear and foreign object unless battery or vegetable matter such as a bean. If insect in ear, use mineral oil to sedate insect.

828.label: Unable to remove the object OR object not visible

185.label: Herpangina
185.description: Throat is often red with vesicules 1-2mm that can rupture resulting in yellow/grayish ulcerations. Often associated with fever, sore throat and headache.

184.label: Ulcer of mouth
184.description:
Look inside the childs mouth for mouth ulcers. Ulcers are painful open sores on the inside of the mouth and lips or the tongue. They may be red or have white coating.

In patients with measles, note that mouth ulcers are different than the small spots called Koplik spots. Koplik spots occur in the mouth inside the cheek during early stages of the measles infection. Koplik spots are small, irregular, bright red spots with a white spot in the centre. They do not interfere with drinking or eating. They do not need treatment.

188.label: >=2 months to < 2 years and >=2 years to <= 14 years

1837.label: Presence of HIV; moderate or severe malnutrition or treatment with nystatin failed

190.label: Oral candidiasis
190.description: White plaques in mouth, most often on tongue, palate and buccal mucosa.

205.label: Local redness or tenderness of neck mass

203.label: Neck mass
203.description: Visible and/or palpable mass/lump on the neck.

217.label: Penile redness and /or swelling
217.description: edemataous erythematous swelling of glans penis and the foreskin

229.label: Cottage-cheese-like/ curdlike discharge
229.description: Vaginal candidiasis often presents with watery to thick white, cottage-cheese-like discharge, accompanied by itch, vaginal soreness or vulvar burning.

237.label: Genital HSV lesion
237.description: Genital HSV: acute onset of multiple, vesicular or ulcerated lesions. May progress through stages of erythema, papules, short-lived vesicles, painful ulcers and crusts. Most often painful.

382.label: Chicken pox lesions
382.description: multiple lesions of different stages: macules, papules, vesicules, crusted papules, may also be present on hairy scalp/genitals. Almost always very itchy, often associated with headache and diffuse muscle pain

1677.label: Fail appetite test
1677.description:
Provide Ready-to-Use Therapeutic Food (RUTF) or equivalent to eat at the consultation:
    Yes: The child fails the appetite test, he/she cannot finish the RUTF portion or equivalent
    No: The child passes the appetite test, he/she canfinish the RUTF portion or equivalent
    Not available: RUTF or equivalent is not available, considered as pass

454.label: Sunken eyes
454.description:
LOOK FOR SUNKEN EYES
The eyes of a child who is dehydrated may look sunken. Decide if you think the eyes are sunken. Then ask the mother if she thinks  her  childs  eyes  look  unusual.  Her  opinion  can  help  you confirm.
NOTE: In a severely malnourished child who is wasted, the eyes may always look sunken, even if the child is not dehydrated. Still use the sign to classify dehydration. 
(IMCI training module, 2014)

278.label: Unable to drink or breastfeed
278.description: The caretaker says the child cannot drink or breastfeed.

284.label: Nb of loose or liquid stools over past 24 hours

287.label: Number of emesis in past 24 hours

242.label: Inguinal Bubo (painful inguinal or femoral lymph nodes)
242.description: Inguinal Bubo: Unilateral or bilateral, tender, sometimes purulent inguinal and/or femoral lymphadenopathy. Develops 2-6 wks after painful ulcer/papules

255.label: History of worms in stool
255.description: Ask if the caregiver has ever seen thin, white worms (5-10 mm in lenght) in the feces or in the anal region of the child.

254.label: Anal or genital night time itching

259.label: Scrotal pain
259.description: The patient reports an acute severe testicular/scrotal pain.

262.label: Testicular tenderness
262.description: Painful, high-riding testicle with absent cremasteric reflex, the scrotal skin can be indurated, red/dark and warm

1855.label: Severe pain or reduction of hernia not possible

444.label: HIV test
444.description:
**Follow normal health facility procedures** 

Bellow are suggested guidance in the case that normal health facility procedures are not clear:

TEST PROCEDURE:
        Apply 10l of serum or plasma (or 20l whole blood) to the sample pad S
of SD Bioline HIV-1/2 3.0 rapid test
and add 4 drops of the assay diluent. 
        Interpret the results within 20 minutes.
        For confirmatory testing use Uni-Gold rapid test. For children < 18 month, PCR is going to be
performed to confirm the HIV status and for children with age > 19 month, ELISA is going to be used.

INTERPRETATION:

 POSITIVE
(two bars): Red bars appear in both the control window
(labeled C) and the patient window (labeled 1 and 2) of the strip. The test result is positive even if the patient bar
appears lighter or darker than the control bar.

NEGATIVE
(one bar): One red bar
appears in the control window of the strip (labelled "C") and no red
bar appears in the patient window of the strip (labelled "T").

INVALID
(no bar): If there is no
red bar in the control window of the strip, and even if a red bar appears in
the patient window of the strip, the result is invalid and should be
repeated.  If it is still invalid dont
use the whole box of test kits from which the kit used was taken off.

266.label: Stiff neck
266.description:
LOOK OR FEEL FOR STIFF NECK

A child with fever and stiff neck may have meningitis. A child with meningitis needs urgent treatment with injectable antibiotics and referral to hospital.

While you talk with the mother during the assessment, look to see if the child moves and bends his neck easily as he looks around. If the child is moving and bending his neck, he does not have a stiff neck.

If you did not see any movement, or if you are not sure, draw the childs attention to his umbilicus or toes. For example, you can shine a flashlight on his toes or umbilicus or tickle his toes to encourage the child to look down. Look to see if the child can bend his neck when he looks down at his umbilicus or toes.

If you still have not seen the child bend his neck himself, ask the mother to help you lie the child on his back. Lean over the child, gently support his back and shoulders with one hand. With the other hand, hold his head. Then carefully bend the head forward toward his chest. If the neck bends easily, the child does not have stiff neck. If the neck feels stiff and there is resistance to bending, the child has a stiff neck. Often a child with a stiff neck will cry when you try to bend the neck. REF WHO IMCI Handbook 2005

2244.label: Is IV or IM artesunate available?

2146.label: YI - Age category in days
2146.description: age in days for young infant under 2 months

2116.label: YI - Is the infant feeding well currently?
2116.description: Maternal report. That is, are they feeding well, not feeding well or not feeding at all?

2117.label: YI - Severe chest indrawing
2117.description: Observed. Must be when infant is calm. Severe chest indrawing indicates the lower chest wall is indrawn on inhalation.

2115.label: YI - Movement
2115.description: On observation. Young infant must be awake. If the infant is sleeping, gently wake him or her.

2114.label: YI - Fastbreathing (RR >=60 BPM) first count
2114.description: Count breaths over one minute and repeat the count a second time if >= 60 BPM to confim the result

2148.label: YI - Fastbreathing (RR >=60 BPM) second count
2148.description: Count a second time the breaths over one minute in a calm child if >= 60 BPM during the first count.

282.label: Severe abdominal palpation (needing referral)
282.description:
Select this as "present" if the abdominal palpation is of great concern, for which the child should be referred for further investigations (US, surgical evaluation)

Signs of severe abdominal palpation include: Diffuse rebound tenderness. Pain to even light touch.

Specific signs of appendicitis include : Right lower quadrant tenderness or rebound tenderness, accentuated when jumping on right foot, pain migrating from the umbilical region associated with fever.

1705.label: Suspicion of severe gastrointestinal bleeding (excessive blood in stool or vomit)
1705.description:
Gastrointestinal bleeding can present as blood in stool or vomit.

Blood in stool: Severe gastrointestinal bleeding can occur in the case of intestinal obstruction (intussusception) in which the child most often presents with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, lethargic, and bloody stools (like "currant jelly"). 

Blood in vomit: Severe gastrointestinal bleeding, presents as large quantity of blood in the vomit and can be due to rupture of esophageal varices, or injury of the esophagus from a foreign object (less commonly gastritis).

Note, not all blood in stool or vomit is gastro-intestinal bleeding, and it is not always severe. Other causes include dysentery, milk or soy induced colitis, anal fissures, epistaxis, or ingesting food that resembles blood.

293.label: Eating a lot less than usual

448.label: <2months; >=2months to <12 months; >=12months to <24 months; >=24 months to 14years

309.label: Duration of joint pain or limp

300.label: Extremity pain
300.description: Localized pain on upper or lower limb

308.label: History of fall or trauma
308.description: Did the child fall, or was the child in an accident, or was the child hit by something that could explain the pain?

304.label: Single joint pain
304.description: Localized pain at rest or pain on movement of a joint, often with limited range or loss of movement

311.label: Sign of wound infection
311.description: Surrounding skin inflammed, red, warm, pus, swelling

2028.label: Persisting fever or no improvement of wound and surrounding skin after > 72 hours of antibiotics?

2030.label: Suture conditions (clean wound < 24h, dirty wound < 6 h)

2033.label: Complicated deep wound needing referral (>5% TBSA, motor deficit, signs of severe infection)

321.label: Suspicion of bone fracture or dislocation

328.label: Burn circumferential
328.description: Circumferential burns, are full thickness burns that go around a finger, arm, leg, or even torso. This blocks the circulation and is dangerous.

2042.label: Sign of surrounding skin infection
2042.description: Surrounding skin inflamed, red, warm, pus, swelling

326.label: Burn size
326.description: The general rule is, the size of the patient's palm is the equivalent of 1% of the total body surface area (TBSA). See figure for TBSA of other body parts.

547.label: < 5% of total body surface area (1% = hand palm)

334.label: Altered mental status
334.description: Altered mental status (agitation, somnolence, repetitive questioning, or slow response to verbal communication)

341.label: Signs of basilar skull fracture
341.description: Retro-auricular/periorbital bruising, blood or CSF runningfrom ear

336.label: Not acting normal
336.description: Since the accident, the child is not acting the same. Not playing as usual, not responding coherently, confused.

340.label: Open skull fracture
340.description: Open skull fracture or compound fracture is when there is a fracture of the skull (splintering of the skull bone) and a break in the skin.

335.label: History of loss of consciousness
335.description: At the moment of the accident did the child loose consciousness (interruption of awareness and no response to people or other environmental stimuli).

2048.label: Worsening of clinical status after 4 hours in clinic
2048.description: Keep the child for surveillance for 4 hours to see the progression of symptoms. If symptoms improve, the child may be okay to return home. If symptoms worsen, referral to a referral/district hospital may be needed.

332.label: Head struck by a high-impact object

344.label: Major car accident
344.description: Pedestrian hit by fast moving car, pedestrian runover by car, passenger in car accident in fast moving car

347.label: Significant exposure to fire or smoke

357.label: Accidental ingestion of potentially harmful entity

2052.label: Drainage of abscess possible at this health facility?
2052.description: Does your health facility have the capacity to perform abscess drainage today?

358.label: Abscess of skin
358.description: Red elevated skin lesion/bump that is painful and sometimes associated with fever. It is full of pus.

369.label: Regression of skin lesion after 72hours of antibiotic treatment

376.label: Ecthyma lesion
376.description: Ulcer covered with yellow crust. Sometimes ulcer with necrotic black eschar

373.label: Other skin lesion
373.description: Including: Pityriasis Versicolor, herpes simplex - oral lesions, impetigo,  heat rash, infectious folliculitis, scarlet fever, and molluscum contagiosum.

375.label: Bullous impetigo
375.description: fragile, flacid bullae with yellow fluid

384.label: Oral herpes
384.description: Single or grouped vesicles often around mouth. Often painful.

388.label: Extensive skin disease
388.description: This is a subjective assessment, as there is no accepted definition of extensive disease. Indications to consider as extensive skin disease include: involvement of more than one body region and size >1-2x patient's palm.

387.label: Tinea corporis
387.description: Often itchy circular or oval red scaling patch or plaque. At later stages central clearing occurs, with spread of raised borders. It is sometimes surrounded by vesicles.

390.label: Tinea capitis
390.description: Often itchy circular or oval red scaling patch or plaque.  At later stages central clearing occurs, with spread of raised borders. Sometimes surrounded by vesicles, pustule formations or a buggy fluctuant mass (kerion). It is often associated with hair loss.

392.label: Scabies
392.description: Itchy (especially at night), small, red papules or vesicles, sometimes with excoriation or burrows. Found mostly in interdigital spaces of the hands and feet, wrists, waistline, and genitals. In infants consider palms and soles

394.label: Urticaria
394.description: Raised, red plaques, often appearing and enlarging very fast. Very itchy, especially at night.

2058.label: < 2 months/ >= 2 to < 6 months / >= 6 to < 24 months/ >= 24 months to < 5 years / > 5 years

397.label: Atopic eczema
397.description:
in infants: Itchy, red (sometimes hypo or hyperpigmentation especially on dark skin), scaly and crusted lesions on cheek, forehead, scalp, or extensor surfaces. Rarely in groin and axilla region.
 in children: Itchy, thick (lichenified) plaques (sometimes hypo or hyperpigmentation especially on dark skin) in flexural surfaces especially elbows, knees, neck, wrist and ankles. Rarely in groin and axilla region.

2199.label: Look for availability of the following treatments. First line treatment is Hydrocortisone cream and second line is Betamethasone cream.

399.label: Pityriasis versicolor
399.description: Hypo/hyperpigmented patches (most often on chest, back and arms). Not itchy.

2064.label: > 6 months of age and no vit A in the past month, and NO RUTF

1704.label: Deep or extensive mouth ulcers
1704.description: In severe cases, they are deep and extensive. Select this option if a child with measles has mouth ulcers which makes it difficult to drink or eat, thus needing admission/referral.

403.label: Molluscum contagiosum
403.description: Flesh-colored or pearly white, small papules with central umbilication. Sometimes associated with itching, not associated with fever

405.label: Non specific viral rash
405.description: Many viruses cause a maculo-papular rash, they can be accompagnied with unspecific symptoms such as fever, headache, muscle, joint or back pain.

407.label: Head lice (pediculosis)
407.description: Excoriated papules and/or nits, nymphs, lice in hair. Very itchy

409.label: Diaper rash
409.description: Hyperpigmented or red rash that is often itchy in the groin/buttock area due to wet diaper that has not been changed frequently

411.label: Scarlet fever rash
411.description: Bright red rash that blanches with pressure, with small papules giving it a sandpaper texture (like pumice stone). It is usually located on face, neck, trunk, arms and legs; palms and soles are not involved. The spread initially starts on the neck, underarm, and groin, and then spreads over the body. The cheeks may be rosy, and a pale area around the mouth. Often associated with sore throat, abdominal pain and emesis. Typically the child presents with strawberry tongue, red tonsils with exudates or petechiae

419.label: Heat rash
419.description:
Heat rash can present as:

Miliaria rubra: Red papules 2-4mm on a red rash. Sometimes causes itching.
or
Miliaria crystallina: Clear, superficial vesicles 1-2mm that look like water droplets found most often on the head, neck and upper trunk.

It is caused by blocked sweat ducts, most often in newborns and those wearing tight fitted clothes.

1738.label: Identifiable source of fever?
1738.description:
- Cough or difficult breathing? If YES, return to complaint categories and select "Respiratory complaint"
- Sore throat, runny nose, or ear infection? If Yes, return to complaint categories and select "Ear, nose, mouth and throat problem"
- Abscess, skin infection, chicken pox, measles rash, or other rash explaining the fever? If YES, return to complaint categories and select "Skin problems"
- Diarrhea, vomiting, or severe abdominal pain? If yes, return to complaint categories, and select "Gastro-intestinal problem"
- Urinary symptoms? If yes, return to complaint categories, and select "Urine, genital problem"
- Limp, single joint pain, joint swelling, pain or refusal to move extremity? If yes, return to complaint categories and select "Trauma, injury, problem"

1740.label: Well appearing
1740.description: Subjective assessment of the child, ideally after one hour of paracetamol if febrile during examination.

440.label: Mother HIV+ or unknown status
440.description: Does the mother have HIV? Or does the mother have an unknown HIV status, and testing the mother is not possible?

439.label: Tested for HIV in the past?
439.description: Has the patient ever had an HIV test?

446.label: Missing vaccination (Vaccinations incomplete)?
446.description: Ask to see the child's vaccination card / Child Health card (Kadi ya kliniki ya mtoto): See if vaccinations are up to date.

456.label: Oral rehydration challenge
456.description:
Oral rehydration challenge: 
LOOK TO SEE HOW THE CHILD DRINKS
Ask the caretaker to offer the child some water in a cup or spoon. Watch the child drink. A child is not able to drink if he is not able to suck or swallow when offered a drink, or vomits everything. A child may not be able to drink because he is lethargic or unconscious. 
(IMCI training module, 2014)

2078.label: >= 2 months to < 6 months / >= 6 months to < 6 years

1707.label: Skin pinch goes back very slowly (>2 seconds)
1707.description:
This skin pinch tests is an important tool for testing dehydration. When a child is dehydrated, the skin loses elasticity. 

To assess dehydration using the skin pinch: 
1.ASK the mother to place the child on the examining table so that the child is flat on his back with his arms at his sides (not over his head) and his legs straight. Or, ask the mother to hold the child so he is lying flat on her lap.
2.USE  YOUR  THUMB  AND  FIRST  FINGER  to  locate  the  area  on  the  childs  abdomen halfway between the umbilicus and the side of the abdomen. Do not use your fingertips because this will cause pain. The fold of the skin should be in a line up and down the childs body.
3.PICK UP all the layers of skin and the tissue underneath them.
4.     HOLD the pinch for one second. Then release it.
5. LOOK  to  see  if  the  skin  pinch  goes  back  very  slowly  (more  than  2  seconds),  slowly, (less than 2 seconds, but not immediately), or immediately. If the skin stays up for even a brief time after you release it, decide that the skin pinch goes back slowly. 

NOTE: The skin pinch test is not always an accurate sign. In a child with severe malnutrition, the skin may go back slowly even if the child is not dehydrated. In a child is overweight or has oedema, the skin may go back immediately even if the child is dehydrated. However you should still use it to classify the childs dehydration. (IMCI training module, 2014)

414.label: Folliculitis
414.description: Pustule or erythematous papules anywhere hair is located, most common sites include the scalp, face, upper trunk, buttocks, legs and the underarm area. It is often itchy, and sometimes putules can be painful. Hair shaft can frequently be seen.

2200.label: Look for availability of the following treatments. First line treatment is Gentian Violet and second line is Sivler sulfadiazine cream

2198.label: Look for availability of the following treatments. First line treatment is Erythromicin and second line is Amoxicillin / clavulanic acid

450.label: Mebendazole or albendazole in the last 6 months?

2194.label: Look for availability of the following treatments. First line treatment is Mebendazole and second line is Albendazole.

452.label: Vitamin A supplementation in the past 6 months?
452.description: Ask to see the child's Child Health card (Kadi ya kliniki ya mtoto): See if vitamin A supplementation is up to date.

2070.label: Transfer to nearby clinic to perform mRDT withing 2 hours possible
2070.description: If the child is well, is not presenting any Central nervous system danger signs, and is able to visit another health facility within 2 hours; transfer the child to another clinic to perform a malaria test.

1745.label: Travel outside district/council within the last month?
1745.description:
Did the patient travel outside of his or her district/council in the last month? 
The patient must have stayed at least one night to qualify as having traveled there.

2186.label: Look for availability of the following treatments. First line treatment is Ceftriaxone and second line is Ampicillin and Gentamicin

2079.label: Currently treated with Ready to use therapeutic food (RUTF)

1673.label: Severe palmar pallor
1673.description: LOOK at the skin of the childs palm. Hold the childs palm open by grasping it gently from the side. Do not stretch the fingers backwards.  This may cause pallor by blocking the blood supply. If it looks pale compared to the caretaker, then palmar pallor is present, if it is very pale or so pale that it looks white thant it is SEVERE palmar pallor. (adapted from IMCI 2014)

1672.label: Severe conjunctival pallor
1672.description: Conjunctivae with very little or no evidence of red color on the anterior rim, which matches the fleshy color of the posterior aspect of the palpebral conjunctiva (REF Aggarwal et al. Anemia 2014)

1698.label: Supsicion of mumps?
1698.description:
Suspicion of Mumps?
Parotid (cheek) swelling (one or both sides) often associated with fever, ear pain, malaise, testicular tenderness (mumps orchitis), jaw pain, and/or headache.

1710.label: Syphilis test
1710.description:
**Follow normal health facility procedures**

Bellow are suggested guidance in the case that normal health facility procedures are not clear:

TEST PROCEDURE:
        Apply 50l of sample (whole blood, serum or plasma) to the sample pad of Alere Determine Syphilis TP rapid test. If using whole blood, add 1 drop of chase buffer 1 minute after applying whole blood to pad. 
        Interpret the results in 15 minutes.

INTERPRETATION OF RESULTS:
 POSITIVE (two bars): Red bars appear in both the control window and the patient window of the strip. The test result is positive even if the patient bar appears lighter or darker than the control bar.

NEGATIVE (one bar): One red bar appears in the control window of the strip and no red bar appears in the patient window of the strip.

INVALID (no bar): If there is no red bar in the control window of the strip, and even if a red bar appears in the patient window of the strip, the result is invalid and should be repeated.  If it is still invalid dont use the whole box of test kits from which the kit used was taken off.

**Note, tests may be falsely negative in 20-30% of tests among patients with a primary syphilis lesion (chancre), another test in one week, or presumptive treatment may be warranted if suspicion is high.

239.label: Primary syphilis lesion (chancre)
239.description: dark, red macule or papule, progressing into erosion, leading to a wellcircumscribed, flat ulcer with a yellow coated base and an indurated, nonundermined wall (chancre). Most often not painful, and usually single lesion

46.label: Recent close contact with somebody with TB
46.description: Close contacts is defined as sharing airspace with somebody with infectious pulmonary tuberculosis for >15 hours a week. This must have occured within the past 12 months.

1746.label: Significant weight loss
1746.description: Poor weight gain, failure to thrive, weight loss, or documented weight loss

1684.label: Jaundice
1684.description:
Does the child have yeloowed skin or sclera? 
It is important to look for jaundice in natural light. To look for jaundice, press the childs skin over the forehead with your fingers to blanch. Remove your fingers and look for yellow discoloration. If there is yellow discoloration, the child has jaundice. Also look for yellow eyes, another sign that the child has jaundice. 
(Adapted from Pediatric Sepsis CoLab 2020 and IMCI 2014)

1708.label: Ampicillin IV/IM
1708.description:
Ampicillin iv, powder for infection (as sodium salt), 250 mg per vial
Preparation of the injection solution: Dissolve the powder in 2.5ml water for injections (source drug.com uk)

formulations.description: administer slowly over a 3- to 5- minute period
formulations.injection_instructions: Add 5 mL Sterile Water for Injection to the 250mg vial and shake ,well until It is well mixed.

1709.label: Gentamicin IM
1709.description:
Gentamicin, IV, ampoule 10mg/ml in 2ml or 40mg/ml in 2ml 
vial containing 20mg (2ml at 10mg/ml) undiluted 
vial containing 80mg (2ml at 40mg/ml) mixed with 6 ml sterile water

formulations.description:
10mg/ml in 2ml ampoule 
Administer undiluted by deep IM route.
formulations.injection_instructions: No dilution needed for IM injection

formulations.description:
Administer undiluted by deep IM route. 
40mg/mL in 2mL ampoule
formulations.injection_instructions: No dilution needed for IM injection

1660.label: Paracetamol po
1660.description:
Paracetamol; Oral; Syrup 125mg/5mL;  Weight based dosage 80mg/Kg	(min dose per kg/day 60; max dose per kg/day 80); 	4 doses per day;  max daily dose: 4000mg;  on demand; paracetamol by mouth, four times a day (roughly every 6hrs) as needed 
for pain or fever	
Oral	Tablet	500mg; breakable by 2

1712.label: Ceftriaxone IV/IM
1712.description:
Ceftriaxone for injection IV or IM, powder for injection of 250 mg
Preparation of solutions for injection: 
IV injection: 250mg powder/vial: add 2.5 ml of water for injection BP
Solutions reconstituted with Lidocaine Hydrochloride BP solution should not be administered intravenously. Dosages greater than 1 g should be divided and injected at more than one site.

formulations.injection_instructions:
"Step 1: The powder for injection should be diluted with 0.9ml water for injection
 Step 2: Add water for injection slowly and then shake vigorously until evenly mixed. The total volume will be approximately 1ml."

1808.label: Refer urgently for inpatient management
1808.description: Refer urgently with caretaker for inpatient management at a health centre or hospital with sufficient capacity to manage the illness of the patient. If referral is not possible, manage the child as described in the national guidelines or WHO Pocket Book for hospital care for children.

1733.label: Prednisolone po
1733.description:
Steroids; po; Tablets 5mg; breakable in 2;  A;  Weight based dosage	1 mg/Kg/days, min:	1;  max :2	1 time per day	
Syrup	5mg/5mL

1732.label: Dexamethasone po
1732.description: Steroids; po; Tablets 0.5mg; breakable in 2; B;  Weight based dosage 0.15 mg/Kg;  min 0.15 ; max 0.5; dose per day: 1

1769.label: No referral: Reasons to return to clinic
1769.description:
"No referral is needed.

Advise the caretaker to bring back the child if the child presents: 
- At any time: Respiratory distress, worsening of difficulty in breathing, is not able to drink or breastfeed, convulsions, new fever, new episode of blood in stool, if the child becomes unconscious, lethargic, or becomes sicker
- After 3 days: Persisting fever
- After 7 days: No improvement of symptoms (some symptoms such as oral aphtous ulcers, oral candidiasis, some skin lesions/rashes may take more than 7 days to improve)

*Consider scheduled follow-up or referral if the child is malnourished, has uncontrolled HIV, or other severe comorbidities.

(adapted from IMCI 2014, based on studies from Kallander et al. PLoS Med, 2018; and Mullany et al. PLoS Med, 2018)

1811.label: Croup counselling
1811.description:
-	Croup often begins without warning in the middle of the night
-	In case of subsequent episode: 
-	keep your child calm, as breathing is often more difficult when upset. The more the child is distressed, the worse their symptoms can become. 
-	If your child is irritable and feverish, give a paracetamol
-	Bring the child outside for fresh-cold air 
-	Go to a healthcare facility if symptoms are getting worse, if the child is struggling to breathe, looks very sick, becomes pale and drowsy or the lips are blue in color
REF: Adapted from Royal Children's Hospital Melbourne fact sheets

1812.label: Ensure adequate fluid and calorie intake
1812.description:
"The child may be eating much less, or eating different foods during illness. Children often lose their appetite during illness. However, they should still be encouraged to eat the types of food recommended for their age, as often as recommended, even if they do not eat much. They should be offered their favourite nutritious foods, if possible, to encourage eating. Offer small feedings frequently. After illness, good feeding helps make up for any weight loss and prevent malnutrition.

During illness an infant or young child loses fluid due to fever, fast breathing, or diarrhoea. The child will feel better and stay stronger if he or she drinks extra fluid to prevent dehydration. Frequent breastfeeding will give the infant nourishment and help prevent dehydration. (IMCI Handbook)"

1758.label: COVID-19 counselling
1758.description:
The patient is presenting signs and symptoms compatible with COVID-19. 
Patients with suspected COVID-19 should be isolated to contain virus transmission (especially to vulnerable populations). Please follow local guidelines in order for the patient to be refered to a designated COVID-19 health facility, community facility or at home (self-isolation). 

Antibiotics are not recommended for treatment or prophylaxis for patients with mild or moderate COVID-19 (unless there is clinical suspicion of a bacterial infection). Of note, few patients with COVID-19 experience a secondary bacterial infection.

If the patient will be self-isolated at home, the following recommendations should be followed:
- Place the patient in a well-ventilated single room (ideally in a different room from others)
- Limit movement of the patient in the house and minimize shared space (keep windows open) if sharing space.
- Wash hands after any type of contact with the patient or their immediate environment.
- A mask should be worn as much as possible by the patient.
- Caregivers should wear a mask when in the same room as the patient.
- Avoid direct contact with body fluids (oral respiratory secretions, and stool).
- Avoid sharing potentially contaminated items (toothbrushes, eating utensils, towels, bed linen, washcloths, clothes)

Advise close contacts of the patient that they are at risk of contracting COVID-19, and must seek care if they develop symptoms and wear face masks and wash hands.

Special attention must be given to limit transmission to vulnerable close-contacts, such as those with chronic diseases (hypertension, diabetes, HIV), and the elderly (>= 60 years).

REF: WHO/2019-nCov/IPC/HomeCare/2020.3

1813.label: Refer for specialized outpatient investigations: hemoptysis
1813.description: The child is coughing up blood, this merits further investigation as it may be a sign of tuberculosis, or of a foreign body in the airway.

1734.label: Budesonide INH
1734.description:
Inhalators; INH; 	Inhalation (aerosol)	100mcg/dose; 200mcg/dose;  	B;	2 time a day; on demand	
2x/day 100 or 200mcg/dose (to facilitate)

1735.label: Salbutamol INH
1735.description:
Inhalators; INH; Metered dose inhaler (aerosol)	100mcg/dose;  2 to 4 doses per day; on demand; 	
2 puffs on demand if difficult breathing

1814.label: Advise on proper inhaler use
1814.description:
Give Inhaled Salbutamol for difficult breathing (wheezing)
USE OF A SPACER*
A spacer is a way of delivering the bronchodilator drugs effectively into the lungs. No child under 5 years
should be given an inhaler without a spacer. A spacer works as well as a nebuliser if correctly used.
 
Repeat up to 3 times every 15 minutes before classifying pneumonia.
Spacers can be made in the following way:
Use a 500ml drink bottle or similar.
Cut a hole in the bottle base in the same shape as the mouthpiece of the inhaler.
This can be done using a sharp knife.
Cut the bottle between the upper quarter and the lower 3/4 and disregard the upper quarter of the bottle.
Cut a small V in the border of the large open part of the bottle to fit to the child's nose and be used as a mask.
Flame the edge of the cut bottle with a candle or a lighter to soften it.
In a small baby, a mask can be made by making a similar hole in a plastic (not polystyrene) cup.
Alternatively commercial spacers can be used if available.
To use an inhaler with a spacer:
Remove the inhaler cap. Shake the inhaler well.
Insert mouthpiece of the inhaler through the hole in the bottle or plastic cup.
The child should put the opening of the bottle into his mouth and breath in and out through the mouth.
A carer then presses down the inhaler and sprays into the bottle while the child continues to breath normally.
Wait for three to four breaths and repeat.

For younger children place the cup over the child's mouth and use as a spacer in the same way.
* If a spacer is being used for the first time, it should be primed by 4-5 extra puffs from the inhaler.
(REF IMCI 2014)

1723.label: Co-trimoxazole po
1723.description: Co-trimoxazole for urinary tract infection or malnutrition, syrup 240/5ml / tablet 480mg (Trimethoprim 80mg, Sulfamethoxazole 400mg) , dosage 8mg TMP/kg/day, 2x/d, dosage based on TMP

1682.description:
ATB	Amoxicillin / clavulanic acid; oral; Suspension : 125mg amoxicillin + 31.5mg clavulanic acid/5mL;  weight based dosage : Amoxicillin 100mg/kg/day	2; min 80; max 100; max daily dose: 1.5g/d	
Tablet 500mg amoxi + 125 mg claculanic acid, breakable in 2

1815.label: Cough or cold or upper respiratory tract infection: Symptomatic care
1815.description:
-           Soothe the throat and relieve the cough with a safe remedy, such as tea with lemon, lime, or honey.
-       Drink fluids: Fluids keep the throat moist and prevent dehydration.
-       Clear secretions from child using a cloth soaked in water that has been twisted to form a pointed wick
(Adapted from IMCI 2014, and Mayo Clinic 2020)

1818.label: Conjunctivitis guidance
1818.description:
-	Cold compresses: fill a bowl with cold water or with ice and water, submerge a clean towel or washcloth into the bowl and then wring it out. Apply it on the eye for 10-20 min, repeat after 2h
-	Advice about high contagiosity, importance of hand hygiene for patient and family members

1765.label: Sodium Chromoglycate 2-4% eye drops
1765.description: Anti-inflammatory; Topical (Eye); Eye drops	2-4%;  dosage based on Age; For 4 - 12 years : 1 drop q6h

formulations.description: Apply 1 drop in the affected eye 4 times a day

1716.label: Chloramphenicol eye drops
1716.description: Chloramphenicol eye drops 0.50%, 1 drop every 3 hours

formulations.description: Chloramphenicol eye drops 0.50%
Ciprofloxacin 0.3% eye drops; 1 drop per affected eye every 3 hours

1820.label: Foreign body removal from the eye
1820.description:
-	Pull down the lower eyelid to see the lower conjunctiva
-	Always check for a foreign body also by everting the upper eyelid (place a cotton swab on the upper eyelid of the closed eye, grasp the eyelashes with your thumb and forefinger and evert the eyelid by using the cotton swab as a fulcrum) 
-	For a visible object, try to trap it with a cotton swab. If the object persists, flush it out by flowing clean water as you hold the eyelid open
-	If many fragments are visible (f.ex. grains of sand), pour a glass of clean, warm water into the eye by holding the child's face up (one person holds the eyelid open, one person pours the water)
-	Avoid removing large, deep or central corneal foreign bodies, refer these

1821.label: Refer for specialized outpatient management: Ophtalmology
1821.description: Refer for specialized outpatient management at a hospital with ophthalmology expertise.

1806.label: Ibuprofen po
1806.description: Non-Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs (NSAID); Oral ; Tablets 200mg; not breakable;  dosage based on Weight  : 30mg/kg; min 15;	max 30; 3 times a days; daily max dose; 1800mg

1827.label: Refer for specialized outpatient management: Dentist
1827.description: Refer for specialized outpatient management with a dentist

formulations.description: Ciprofloxacin ear drops 0.3%

1830.label: Dry the ear by wicking (if ear discharge present)
1830.description:
Dry the ear at least 3 times daily.
Roll clean absorbent cloth or soft, strong tissue paper into a wick.
Place the wick in the child's ear.
Remove the wick when wet.
Replace the wick with a clean one and repeat these steps until the ear is dry.
(Adapted from IMCI 2014)

1831.label: Refer for specialized outpatient management: Ear, nose, and throat
1831.description: Refer to health facility with expertise with ear problems including hearing loss, and extraction of foreign body in ear.

1849.label: Consider repeating pregnancy test in 2 weeks

1843.label: Safe sex counselling
1843.description:
-	Provide health education on safe sex
-	Discuss importance of using condoms to prevent acquisition of STIs, HIV, and unwanted pregnancies. 
-	Provide condoms if available

1850.label: Pregnancy counselling
1850.description:
-	Visit the health centre at least 4 times during the pregnancy, even without problems. Additional visits if there is any concern about mother and/or baby 
-	Eat more and healthier foods (incl. more fruits, vegetables, beans, pasteurized cheese and milk)
-	Avoid lifting heavy objects, rest when you can 
-	Take iron tablets as explained by the health worker
-	Sleep under a bednet treated with insecticide 
-	Do not take medication unless prescribed at the health centre 
-	Do not drink alcohol or smoke
-	Use a condom correctly in every sexual relation to prevent STI or HIV, if you or the companion are at risk of infection 
-	Go immediately to hospital if: vaginal bleeding, convulsions, severe headache with blurred vision, fever and too weak to go out of bed, severe abdominal pain, fast/difficult breathing (danger signs)
-	Go to health centre if water breaks, if painful contractions every 20 min. or less and if presence of bloody sticky discharge (signs of labour)

1851.label: Refer or advise to seek obstetric clinic

1859.label: Gentian Violet (half strength) solution
1859.description:
Powder reconstituted to 0.25% with water

"For mouth ulcers: Treating mouth ulcers controls infection and helps the child to eat. Teach the mother to treat mouth ulcers with half-strength gentian violet. Gentian violet used in the mouth should be half-strength (0.25%), not full-strength (0.5%). Give the following information. 

Tell the mother:

 Her child will start eating normally sooner if she paints the mouth ulcers in her childs mouth. It is important that the child eats. 
 Clean the childs mouth. Wrap a clean soft cloth around her finger. Dip it in salt water. Wipe the mouth.
  Use a clean cloth or a cotton-tipped stick to paint gentian violet on the mouth ulcers. The gentian violet will kill germs that cause the ulcers. Put a small amount of gentian violet on the cloth or stick. Do not let the child drink the gentian violet.
  Treat the mouth ulcers 2 times per day, in the morning and evening.
  Treat the mouth ulcers for 5 days and then stop.

Wrap a clean cloth around your finger and dip it into salt water. Show the mother how to first wipe the childs mouth clean. Then paint half of the childs mouth with halfstrength gentian violet.

Ask the mother to practise. Watch her wipe the childs mouth clean and paint the rest of the ulcers with gentian violet. Comment on the steps she did well and those that need to be improved. Give the mother a bottle of half-strength gentian
 violet to take home. Tell her to return to the clinic if the mouth ulcers get worse or if the child is not able to drink or eat.
Before the mother leaves, ask checking questions. 
For example, ask:

What will you use to clean the childs mouth?
When will you wash your hands?
How often will you treat the childs mouth? For how many days?
If she anticipates any problems providing the treatment, help her to solve them."

1834.label: Oral aphtous ulcer advice
1834.description:
Oral aphthous ulcers and herpangina usually resolve on its own. These are things that could help:

-       Drink a lot of water
-       Rinse mouth with a mixture of water and salt or cold black tea  2-3x/day
-       Avoid spicy or very hot foods/beverages
-       Brush your teeth gently

1763.label: Miconazole Gel 2% po (for mouth)
1763.description:
Antifungal; Oral	Gel	2%; 	dosage based on Age; for All ages:	5mL				2	

Apply 5mL on lesions 2 times a day

formulations.description: Apply 5mL of miconazole ointment twice a day in mouth.

1836.description: If lesion on breast (flaky or shiny) or painful breastfeeding, advise mother to treat with topical miconazole 2%

1839.label: Refer for specialized outpatient investigation: neck mass
1839.description:
Refer to referral/district hospital for specialized outpatient investigation.
TB, tumor, or other complicated infection must be investigated.

1841.label: Balanitis symptomatic care
1841.description:
As long as symptoms persist, advise patient sitz bath 2-3 times per day:

Sitz bath: Soaking of the penis in clean, warm water containing a weak salt solution for 10-15 min

1842.label: Vulvovaginitis care
1842.description:
-	Advice to avoid local irritations by wearing loose cotton underwear and by avoiding tight jeans, local irritans like perfumed soaps, excessing use of soap 
-	Vinegar Sitz baths: add 1-2 spoons of white vinegar to hand warm water and soak for 10-15 min., rinse and pat dry 
-	Cold compresses: fill a bowl with cold water or with ice and water, submerge a clean towel or washcloth into the bowl and then wring it out. Apply for 10 min, pat dry 
-	Consider deworming with Mebendazole (therapeutic) if presence of anal and/or nighttime itch

formulations.description: 4 tablets of 250mg, or 2 tablets of 500mg

 Step 2: Add water for injection slowly and then shake vigorously until evenly mixed. The total volume will be approximately 1ml."

1844.label: Partner management
1844.description: Advise the partner or partners to visit health facility for treatment (if not possible, provide treatment for the partner(s)

1845.label: Ask for sexual abuse (only if resources are available to help)
1845.description: If resources are available to help victims of sexual abuse, ask if the patient was a victim of sexual abuse. If they were, be empathetic and supportive, refer the child to the appropriate organization that manages sexual abuse (Social welfare, health and police; social services and child protection).

1797.label: Clotrimazole (genital) cream 1%
1797.description: Antifungal; Topical (vulvovaginal); Cream 1%; 1	time a day

1800.description:
Antifungal; Oral; Capsule 50mg or 150mg; not breakable; Age 8-14 years	: 150mg	 1 time a day; daily max dosage: 150mg			
2nd line for vaginal candidiasis, single dose
